Tamil Nadu India 1879
a 16 year old boy named venkataraman
Aya later to be known as Ramana maharshi
is alone in his uncle's house and is
suddenly overcome by an intense Spear of
death
instead of running from this fear he
decides to investigate it
lays down making his body still and
imagines himself dying
he asks himself what it means to die
what dies and what remains after death
as he plunges into this self-inquiry he
finds that although his body could die
his Consciousness or I sense cannot
this experience led to a profound
realization
venkataramanaya discovered that his true
nature was not the physical body or the
fleeting mind but the Eternal and
unchanging self which she later referred
to as the I I or self he became detached
from worldly matters and his academic
Pursuits losing interest in school
friends and family
his life took a dramatic turn and he
left home for the Holy Mountain
arunachala where he spent the rest of
his days as Ramana maharshi a revered
Guru and Sage guiding others towards the
realization of their own true self after
50 years of teaching Ramana maharshi was
diagnosed with cancer which gradually
weakened his body
despite the physical suffering Ramana
maharshi remained remarkably Serene and
unperturbed embodying the teachings he
had shared with countless Seekers
throughout his life
when asked about his dying Ramallah said
they say I am dying
but I am not going away
where would I go I am here

who or what is it that dies with such

resolved attention in its source once

she achieved Enlightenment by realizing

Ramana mahashi went on to teach the
practice of self-inquiry with a simple
question Who Am I the essence of this
practice lies in directing one's
attention inward shifting Focus from

fundamental nature of the self by
consistently keeping this question in
mind who am I one moves Beyond
superficial layers of conditioned
thoughts emotions and identities and
rests in their Source the pure awareness
that underlies all experiences

our denial of death has profound
implications not only for ourselves but
as being the dominant cause of much of
human history
in the best-selling book the denial of
death by Ernest Becker the author
explores the profound impact of
humankind's denial of death our denial
of death gives rise to a multitude of
problems that affect individuals and
society as a whole first and foremost
the denial of death leads to the
suppression of existential anxieties in
the avoidance of confronting the
finitude of human existence
this avoidance manifests in various ways
such as the pursuit of material wealth
status and power as a means of creating
a false sense of immortality
this obsession with external validation
and the fear of death breeds
competitiveness aggression and the
exploitation of others resulting in
social hierarchies violence and
Injustice
moreover the denial of death hamper's
authentic self-expression as individuals
strive to conform to societal norms and
expectations suppressing their true
desires and passions Becca argues that
by acknowledging the reality of
mortality embracing our vulnerability
and finding meaning beyond the fear of
death we can lead more authentic and
fulfilling lives as well as fostering a
healthier and more compassionate Society

the previous book mentioned the denial
of death by Ernest Becker is a highly
regarded book on the subject however it
is not specifically focus on the process
of death and dying
instead it examines how the awareness of
death shapes human behavior and the
strategies individuals employ to cope
with the fear of death and of course a
well-known spiritual Classic on death
and dying is the Tibetan Book of the
Dead
the Tibetan Book of the Dead is a sacred
Buddhist text that serves as a guide for
individuals during the transitional
State between death and rebirth offering
insights on the nature of reality
Consciousness and the path to liberation
here are five other excellent and
insightful books on death and dying the
Tibetan book of living and dying by
sogiar and ponche this book offers a
profound exploration of Life Death in
the afterlife from a Tibetan Buddhist
perspective
it provides practical advice on how to
prepare for death and support loved ones
during the dying process being mortal
medicine and what matters in the end by
Atul gawande atula gawande a renowned
surgeon examines the modern approach to
death and dying highlighting the
importance of providing compassionate
and personalized care to individuals
facing terminal illnesses
he addresses the need to prioritize
quality of life over medicinal
interventions
when breath becomes the air by Paul
kalanithi appointed Memoir by a
neurosurgeon diagnosed with terminal
lung cancer
this book Chronicles his journey from
Doctor to Patient Colony Theory reflects
on life death and the search for meaning
offering profound insights into The
Human Experience The Death of Ivan
Ilitch by Leo tolstein in this classic
Novella Tolstoy explores the existential
crisis faced by Ivan Ilitch a
high-ranking Russian official as he
grapples with his intending death
the story delves Into the profound
questions of the meaning of life and the
inevitability of mortality easy death
spiritual wisdom on the ultimate
transcending of death and everything
else
this book delves into the nature of
death offering guidance on how to
approach the dying process with
understanding and acceptance it explores
the spiritual dimensions of death and
the potential for transformation and
liberation
death has been a subject of
Act of inquiry throughout history
lucretius argued that death does not
truly exist because either we are not
there to experience it or if something
continues after the death of the body
then actual death has not occurred while
lucretius offered a logical perspective
on death many spiritual and
philosophical traditions provide

prepare for the unknown many spiritual
Traditions emphasize purifying attention
and practicing surrender while the life
and teachings of Ramana muharshi
illustrate the power of self-inquiry and
surrender in the face of death
recognizing the inevitability of death
